newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa takes a tumble, March below support.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa takes a tumble, March below support.

text.p: London cocoa futures took a tumble on long liquidation but late bargain-hunting helped some contracts to finish off their lows, traders said.
Benchmark March contract sank to a low of 917 stg a tonne after breaching the previous support at 920 stg. But it came back to end the day at 920, still a 12 stg loss.

Traders could not pinpoint any fresh fundamental factors but some said overnight news by a UK crop forecaster who reiterated that the Ivorian 1996/97 crop could be at least one million tonnes could have driven the market lower.
The projection came a day after an Ivorian diplomat estimated the total crop at 850,000 to 900,00 tonnes including the mid crop because the weather has not been kind this year.
"It came off a bit on the Robert Fish comments but overall the market still holding within the immedidate 900-950 stg range," said one. Fish is the managing director of crop forecaster PCR Ltd.
News Ghana cocoa purchases to sixth week of the 1996/97 season ending November 21 fell to 18,529 tonnes from 28,686 in the same period a year earlier was viewed as bullish.
But traders said the news, along with some latest Ivorian arrival figures, had no positive impact on the market.
"The market won't do much with the sizeable cocoa in the hands of a trade house hanging over the market," said one.
Volume totalled 5,180 lots. The active March/March switch was trading at 70-72 stg.
